did.abstract: Archivist and historian; collection of photo prints and photo negatives, made by various state agencies, and relating primarily to rural landscapes, road construction projects, and the construction of state buildings.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection (donor no. 7596) was the gift of Leroy Barnett, 1988-1990.

accruals.p: No further additions to the collections are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Leroy Barnett Photograph Collection, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Leroy Barnett is a researcher and historian of Michigan related topics.

scopecontent.p: The Leroy Barnett collection consists of ten series of photographs: Michigan State Agriculture Department, Michigan State Highway Department, John C. Mackie, Lloyd Clair Hulbert, Construction Projects (1947-1965), Postcards, Michigan National Guard, Michigan Department of Conservation, Libraries, and Events and Monuments.

The photographs of the Michigan State Agriculture Department cover the period 1928 to 1948. Only three activities of the department are recorded here: the 1928 Upper Peninsula State Fair in Escanaba, Agriculture Department indoor and field laboratories, and cherry canning and factory work in Traverse City.

did.unittitle: Kraft Foods cheese manufacturing plant, Pinconning, Mich.

scopecontent.p: The Michigan State Highway Department photographs document the activities of that department from the 1911 through the 1965. The series of photographs depicts rural road construction sites, road crews and equipment, and roads and highways. Arrangement is alphabetical by Michigan county. Large numbers of photos are available for Ingham, Kent, Livingston and Wayne Counties. Of particular interest are the photographs of drawings and models of proposed construction, which may be found in the Chippewa, Kent, Livingston, and Wayne county folders and in a folder especially for those signed by Al Roth. An interesting feature of the Wayne County photographs is the documentation of the construction of the Edsel Ford and John C. Lodge Expressways in Detroit.

did.unittitle: Berrien (Paw Paw, Mich.; State Line Dance Tavern)
Mackinaw (Labor Day traffic at St. Ignace) 1941
Michigan State Highway Department, John C. Mackie 1957-1960

scopecontent.p: The third series concerns John C. Mackie, State highway Commissioner from 1957 to 1964. The photographs in this series illustrate his activities as Commissioner from 1957-1960. Mackie presided over many projects designed to strengthen Michigan's highway and interstate systems. The pictures are mainly of Mackie and other individuals at highway opening ceremonies or other department functions.

The Lloyd Clair Hulbert photographs were taken by Hulbert from 1927 to 1938. The series is arranged alphabetically by Michigan county. The photos are exclusively of rural areas. Large numbers of photos exist for Alpena, Ingham, Lapeer, Tuscola, and Washtenaw counties. The Washtenaw County pictures are of the Huron River Valley and the Saline area. Generally southeastern Michigan is undocumented here: no photographs are available for Wayne, Oakland, Monroe, or Lenawee counties. Some photographs have accompanying negatives.

With the exception of the Michigan State Fair photographs the state sponsored Construction Projects series consists of construction photos of various state-owned buildings. The Michigan State Fair photographs include a few construction pictures, but also many shots of completed but empty fair buildings and of the Fair in session during 1947.

The Construction series is in the form of spiral bound booklets of photographs. It is arranged by type of institution then alphabetically by the name of the institution. Within each institution arrangement is alphabetically by name of building. The photographs in this series document construction projects undertaken by the State between 1947 and 1965. Both original construction and alterations to existing structures are included. The collection is especially strong in mental health facility construction projects. Dates have been noted on the contents list when they are known. If no date is listed, the date of the photographs in that book are not known. Many of the photographs also document men working on the various construction projects. These have been noted only when they are especially numerous or interesting for some reason.

scopecontent.p: The Postcard series consists of postcards appearing to be from the 1930s and 1940s, although undated. The postcards are mostly pictures of Michigan resort areas and include some photographs of hotels or inns, some of individual family cabins, and some of downtown areas. They are arranged alphabetically by name of town except for a few folders which include postcards not identified by town. These are: Benzie State Park, Glen Lake, Lake County, and Wolf Lake State Fish Hatchery. They are interfiled alphabetically with the rest of the series. Very few include people and these have been noted in the box list. A personal name index to the family cabins is appended to this finding aid.

scopecontent.p: The Michigan National Guard series documents in photographs various times when the National Guard was called up during the 1950s and 1960s. These include various tornadoes between 1953 and 1965, the moving of a hospital in Adrian in 1957, the Essex Wire Corporation strike in Hillsdale in 1964, which involved units from Grand Rapids, Battle Creek, Flint, Brian Center, and Dowagiac, and a civil disturbance in Detroit in 1968. These subseries are arranged chronologically by the earliest date in each subseries. Arrangement within each subseries is also chronological. The negatives for many of these photographs are included in the collection and can be found clipped to the back of their corresponding photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Department of Conservation series documents a great variety of activities of the Department in the 1930s and early 1940s. It is especially rich in wildlife conservation photographs, including the regulation of fishing and hunting.
